p: While other mechanical variables show a typical trend of a temperature-induced improvement in performance, this is not consistently shown in the literature considering sustained muscle activity. Work by James et al. (2012 ) reported that the endurance of iliotibialis muscle isolated from Xenopus tropicalis, measured via a change in maximal work loop power over a protocol of repeated activations, increased with temperature ( Fig. 4). A temperature-induced improvement in fatigue resistance has been reported in previous work using both protocols of repeated isometric tetani and cycles of active shortening ( Roots et al., 2009 ). Conversely, there is conflicting evidence that increased temperature has limited effects on fatigue resistance ( Place et al., 2009 , Nocella et al., 2013 ) or may even cause fatigue to occur more quickly ( Segal et al., 1986 ).
